title: Randi Rhodes Show - September 23 2010
description:
Today, big parts of healthcare reform kick inÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¦ and Republicans announced their plans to kick it to death.

On the positive side, many of the provisions of President ObamaÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s healthcare reform begin today. After today, a lot of the pre-existing conditions in the healthcare system itself will cease to exist. Starting now, insurance companies will no longer be allowed to exclude children because of pre-existing health conditions. Using the term ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œpre-existing conditionÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ about a young child is tantamount to saying they were just born wrong. After today insurers can no longer impose lifetime limits on coverage. That should extend a few lifetimesÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¦ but then I guess thatÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s basically what health insurers were afraid of in the first place. Also, now kids can stay on their parentsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ policies up to age 26, which makes a lot of sense. With the way the economy is, most people under 30 are still living with their parents anyway. And now insurers canÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t drop you after you get sick if they can find a technical mistake on your application. So if you have a problem with your colon, you canÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t be dropped because of a misplaced semi-colon on your application. Speaking of which, now preventive procedures, like colonoscopies, mammograms and immunizations must be covered without co-paymentsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½because the only thing worse than having your breasts mashed into tortillas is being charged to have it done. Free colonoscopies are good news, too. Now you canÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t be charged for having a camera put up your butt, provided of course, that itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s being done by a doctor.
